===Illinois=== *'''Statewide smoking ban''': On January 1, 2008, the [[Smoke Free Illinois Act]] went into effect, banning smoking in all enclosed workplaces, including bars, restaurants, and casinos, and within {{convert|15|ft|m}} of such places; exempts certain retail tobacco stores, private and semiprivate rooms in nursing homes occupied exclusively by smokers, no more than 25% of designated smoking rooms in hotels/motels on the same floor, and private residences.<ref name=sfia>{{cite web |url=http://www.ilga.gov/legislation/publicacts/fulltext.asp?Name=095-0017 |title=Illinois Public Act 095-0017: "Smoke Free Illinois Act" |publisher=Ilga.gov |date=June 30, 2005 |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref> Smoking is prohibited in private residences when defined as a place of employment such as when used for child care or foster care.<ref name=sfia/> Local governments may regulate smoking more strictly than the state.<ref name=sfia/>
HB 1310: a proposal in January 2012 to once again permit smoking in bars, casinos, adult entertainment venues, and private clubs failed in the [[Illinois House of Representatives|Illinois House]] 30-82.
[[Chicago]] has had its own Clean Indoor Air Ordinance since 1988.<ref>[https://www.cityofchicago.org/dam/city/depts/cdph/environmental_health_and_food/ChicagoMunicipalCode732.pdf 1988 Chicago Clean Indoor Air Ordinance (PDF)]</ref> The Chicago Clean Indoor Air Act was updated to mention [[e-cigarettes]] in 2014, making it the first [[List of US cities by population|major U.S. city]] to legislate e-cigarette use.<ref name="Clean Indoor">{{cite web |url=http://www.cityofchicago.org/city/en/depts/cdph/supp_info/tabacco_alcohol_drug_abuse/smoke_free_illinoisact.html |title=Clean Indoor Air Ordinance (No Smoking: Including E-Cigarettes) |publisher=City of Chicago |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140223051610/http://www.cityofchicago.org/city/en/depts/cdph/supp_info/tabacco_alcohol_drug_abuse/smoke_free_illinoisact.html |archivedate=February 23, 2014 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> The [[Chicago Park District]]'s Board of Commissioners has discussed banning all forms of smoking in Chicago parks, beaches, play lots and other facilities, but there is not yet a municipal ordinance.
As of January 1, 2018, the minimum legal age to purchase tobacco products and e-cigarettes in unincorporated areas of [[Lake County, Illinois]] is 21 years.<ref>[http://chicago.suntimes.com/news/lake-county-first-in-illinois-to-raise-tobacco-purchase-age-to-21/ Lake County first in Illinois to raise tobacco purchase age to 21] ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'', September 13, 2017</ref>
===Indiana=== *'''Statewide smoking ban excluding bars, and casinos.''' Effective July 1, 2012, after having been signed into law by [[Governor of Indiana|Governor]] [[Mitch Daniels]] on March 19, 2012, Indiana's 1993 statewide Clean Indoor Air Law was repealed and replaced by a new chapter of the Indiana Code titled "Prohibition on Smoking." The new chapter bans smoking in all enclosed public places and workplaces in Indiana and within {{convert|8|ft|m}} of an entrance thereto, except as exempted.<ref name=indianaban>{{cite web |url=http://www.in.gov/legislative/bills/2012/PDF/HE/HE1149.1.pdf |title=2012 Indiana House Bill 1149-1 |format=PDF |accessdate=December 1, 2013}}</ref> The law exempts: (1) [[horse racing]] facilities including off-track betting parlors; (2) [[riverboat]]s; (3) all indoor portions of casinos and other licensed gaming facilities; (4) [[cigar bar]]s and [[hookah]] lounges; (5) [[private club]]s; (6) retail tobacco stores; (7) bars and taverns (defined as ''any business with a liquor license'' that does not allow in persons under 21 years of age); and (8) cigar manufacturers.<ref name=indianaban/> The law expressly allows local governments to enact more stringent smoking restrictions.<ref name=indianaban/> *Attempts in the [[Indiana General Assembly]] to enact a ban on smoking in all workplaces in Indiana, including all bars and restaurants, have '''failed''' every year since 2007. In April 2007, the [[Indiana Senate]] removed a smoking ban from a health care funding bill passed by the [[Indiana House of Representatives]], and in January 2008, a proposed statewide smoking ban introduced by Rep. [[Charlie Brown (Indiana politician)|Charlie Brown]] died in a House committee without a vote or debate.<ref>"Indiana Smoking Ban Dies in House Committee", ''The Associated Press'', January 28, 2008</ref> In April 2009, another proposed statewide ban introduced by Rep. Brown was passed in the House by a vote of 70–26 after being amended to exempt restaurants, bars, and casinos, and then did not receive a committee hearing in the Senate.<ref>[http://www.post-trib.com/news/elections/1539578,gasmoking.article John Byrne, "Statewide smoking ban now appears dead," ''Post Tribune of Northwest Indiana'', April 23, 2009] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090430114236/http://www.post-trib.com/news/elections/1539578%2Cgasmoking.article |date=April 30, 2009 }}.</ref> In February 2010, another proposed ban by Rep. Brown was denied a committee hearing or vote in the Senate after having been passed by the House, 73-26.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wndu.com/hometop/headlines/83591347.html |title=Mark Peterson, "Smoking ban debate over in Indiana," ''WNDU-16'', February 4, 2010 |publisher=Wndu.com |date=February 4, 2010 |accessdate=December 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130209122831/http://www.wndu.com/hometop/headlines/83591347.html |archivedate=February 9, 2013 |df=mdy-all}}</ref> In April 2011, a Senate committee voted 8–1 to reject a statewide ban exempting bars, casinos, private clubs, retail tobacco shops, and nursing homes, which also had been introduced by Rep. Brown and previously had passed the House, 68-31.<ref>{{cite web |last=Carden |first=Dan |url=http://www.nwitimes.com/niche/inbusiness/health-care/article_8a92408e-e7c7-5367-84e7-47bd63c6554e.html |title=Dan Carden, "Smoking ban dies in Senate", ''Northwest Indiana Times'', April 11, 2011 |publisher=Nwitimes.com |date=April 11, 2011 |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref> The ban that ultimately was enacted in 2012 passed the House as a complete ban on smoking in all workplaces in Indiana, including all bars and restaurants (and authored again by Rep. ===Kansas=== *'''Statewide smoking ban''': On July 1, 2010, after being signed into law by [[Governor of Kansas|Governor]] [[Mark Parkinson (Kansas politician)|Mark Parkinson]] on March 12, 2010, an amendment to Kansas' 1987 statewide smoking law took effect, banning smoking statewide in all enclosed, indoor workplaces in Kansas.<ref name=ksban>[http://www.kslegislature.org/bills/2010/2221.pdf H.B. 2221 (Kan. 2010)] {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> The law will exempt only (1) casino and racetrack gaming floors, (2) the entire area of a private club that was in existence on January 1, 2009, (3) designated areas in any private club where persons under 18 are prohibited, (4) [[tobacconist]]s, (5) designated hotel and motel smoking rooms, (6) designated smoking areas in nursing homes and healthcare facilities, (7) and all outdoor areas, unless within a 10' radius of an entryway to a public building.<ref name=ksban/> The amendment will not change the original law's provision allowing local governments to regulate smoking more stringently than the state,<ref name=ksban/><ref name="K.S.A. 21-4013">K.S.A. 21–4013</ref> which the [[Kansas Supreme Court]] reiterated in 2007 upon a bar owner's challenge to [[Lawrence, Kansas|Lawrence]]'s local smoking ban.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kscourts.org/cases-and-opinions/opinions/supct/2007/20070622/96838.htm |title=Steffes v. City of Lawrence, 284 Kan. 380, 160 P.3d 843 (2007) |publisher=Kscourts.org |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref> On June 30, 2010, the District Court of Shawnee County, Kansas, issued a preliminary injunction prohibiting the statewide smoking ban from taking effect in 31 private clubs established after January 1, 2009, until it settles a lawsuit against the state by those clubs.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kmbc.com/news/24101302/detail.html |title=KS Judge Blocks Parts Of Smoking Law, KMBC-9 TV, Kansas City, Mo., June 30, 2010 |publisher=Kmbc.com |date=June 30, 2010 |accessdate=December 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120307131009/http://www.kmbc.com/news/24101302/detail.html |archivedate=March 7, 2012 |df=mdy-all}}</ref>

===Maine=== *'''Statewide smoking ban''': Effective January 1, 2004, laws from 1985 and 1999 were expanded such that smoking is banned statewide in all workplaces and public places in Maine, including bars and restaurants.<ref name=mestateban>{{cite web |url=http://www.mainelegislature.org/legis/statutes/22/title22sec1542.html |title=Me. Rev. Stat. tit. 22, § 1542 |publisher=Mainelegislature.org |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref> The law exempts places open to the public during hours when it is closed, stage performances involving smoking, smoking for religious rituals, factories where labor unions have contracted to have smoking areas, designated areas in hospitals, designated hotel/motel smoking rooms, private residences except when used as a childcare or healthcare facility, beano and bingo halls, tobacco specialty stores, and off-track betting parlors that were in existence on June 30, 2003.<ref name=mestateban/> The state law exempts private clubs (Elks, American Legion, VFW etc.) under certain conditions. The state law is silent as to whether local governments may regulate smoking more strictly than the state, though as of April 2009 no local government in Maine has done so.<ref name=anrmunilist/> Effective September 1, 2008, smoking is banned in any car when a person under the age of 16 is present, though no driver may be pulled over or searched solely for violation of this law.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mainelegislature.org/legis/statutes/22/title22sec1549.html |title=Me. Rev. Stat. tit. 22, § 1549 |publisher=Mainelegislature.org |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref>
===Maryland=== *'''Statewide smoking ban''': On February 1, 2008, the Maryland Clean Indoor Air Act of 2007 went into effect, banning smoking in all public transportation vehicles, enclosed public places, and enclosed workplaces, including bars, restaurants, casinos, and private clubs.<ref name="md_1">{{cite web |url=http://mlis.state.md.us/2007RS/chapters_noln/Ch_502_hb0359E.pdf |title=MD Clean Indoor Air Act of 2007 (House Bill 359) |format=PDF |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref> The Act exempts private residences and vehicles while not being used as a childcare or healthcare facility, designated hotel/motel smoking rooms, retail tobacco stores, cigar lounges and hookah bars, other tobacco-related workplaces such as importers and distributors, facilities where smoking research is conducted, psychiatric facilities, long-term care facilities, hospitals where a doctor has authorized a patient to smoke, and any business that has applied for and received a waiver allowing smoking (though all waivers expired on January 1, 2011).<ref name="md_1"/> Local governments may regulate smoking more strictly than the state, though not less strictly.<ref name="md_1"/>
===Massachusetts=== *'''Statewide smoking ban''': Effective July 1, 2004, smoking is banned in all enclosed public places and workplaces, including bars and restaurants.<ref name=massban>{{cite web |url=http://www.mass.gov/legis/laws/mgl/270-22.htm |title=Mass. Gen. L. ch. 70, § 22 |publisher=Mass.gov |date=January 1, 2006 |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref> The law exempts private clubs when not open to the public, private residences except when used as a business for healthcare or childcare, designated hotel/motel smoking rooms, retail tobacco stores, licensed cigar or hookah bars, stage performances involving smoking, places where smoking-related scientific research is occurring, religious ceremonies involving smoking, outdoor areas, designated areas in nursing homes as approved by the state, and other tobacco-related workplaces such as farms and distributors.<ref name=massban/> Local governments and boards of health may regulate smoking more strictly than the state.<ref name=massban/> *[[Boston, Massachusetts|Boston]], February 9, 2009, banned by the Boston Public Health Commission on outside patios of bars and restaurants; also banned on February 9, 2019 (10 years later than the other new restrictions) in cigar and hookah bars, unless the establishment obtains an additional 10-year exemption. Additionally, smoking is banned in all hotel rooms in the city of Boston. Tobacco products can not be sold at educational institutions or health care institutions including pharmacies and stores having pharmacies within.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.boston.com/news/health/blog/2008/12/smoking_restric.html |author=Gideon Gil |title=Boston bans cigarette sales in drug stores but delays cigar bar closings |work=The Boston Globe |date=December 11, 2008 |accessdate=December 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090201072423/http://boston.com/news/health/blog/2008/12/smoking_restric.html |archivedate=February 1, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=CVS decision to ban tobacco sales is hailed |url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/lifestyle/health-wellness/2014/02/05/cvs-pharmacy-ban-tobacco-sales-hailed-visionary-move/I7I7qYTyf4yXaWhhWeyGwJ/story.html |work=[[The Boston Globe]] |date=February 5, 2014 |first=Deborah |last=Kotz}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Boston Public Health Commission Regulation Restricting the Sale of Tobacco Products in the City of Boston |url=http://www.bphc.org/whatwedo/tobacco-free-living/Documents/TobaccoRestrictionRegulation_12_08.pdf}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/articles/2008/12/12/hub_enacts_strict_ban_on_tobacco_sales/?page=full |title=Hub enacts strict ban on tobacco sales |first=Stephen |last=Smith |date=December 12, 2008 |work=The Boston Globe}}</ref>
===Michigan=== *'''Statewide smoking ban''': On May 1, 2010, after being signed into law by [[Governor of Michigan|Governor]] [[Jennifer Granholm]] on December 18, 2009, the Dr. Ron Davis Law took effect, banning smoking statewide in all enclosed, indoor workplaces in Michigan, as well as the outdoor patios of bars and restaurants.<ref name=miban>{{cite web |url=http://www.legislature.mi.gov/documents/2009-2010/billenrolled/House/pdf/2009-HNB-4377.pdf |title=2009 Michigan House Bill 4377 |format=PDF |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.michigan.gov/documents/mdch/FAQMISmokeFreeFINAL_314723_7.pdf |title=Michigan Government Smoking Ban FAQ |format=PDF |accessdate=March 25, 2015}}</ref> The law exempts only [[cigar bar]]s, retail tobacco stores, private home offices, company vehicles including commercial trucks, and Detroit's three casinos' gambling floors.<ref name=miban/> The law is silent as to whether local governments may regulate smoking more strictly than the state, though it prohibits state or local health departments from enacting any smoking rules different than the law.<ref name=miban/>
===Minnesota=== *'''Statewide smoking ban''': On October 1, 2007, the [[Freedom to Breathe Act]] went into effect, expanding the existing Clean Indoor Air Act of 1975 so as to ban smoking statewide in all enclosed workplaces in Minnesota, including public transportation, bars, and restaurants.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.revisor.leg.state.mn.us/statutes/?id=144.414&year=2008 |title=Minn. Rev. Stat. § 144.414 |publisher=Revisor.leg.state.mn.us |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref> The Act exempts designated rooms in nursing homes, designated areas in psychiatric facilities, places where scientific studies related to smoking occur, private homes and residences not in use as a place of employment, designated hotel/motel smoking rooms, retail tobacco shops, heavy commercial vehicles, farm vehicles and construction equipment, buildings on family farms, the Minnesota disabled veterans' rest camp, smoking by [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|American Indian]]s as part of a traditional spiritual or cultural ceremony, stage performances involving smoking, and outdoor areas.<ref>{{cite web |title=Minnesota Clean Indoor Air Act |publisher=Emily Cleveland |url=http://www.house.leg.state.mn.us/hrd/issinfo/ssmciaa.pdf |date=July 2007 |accessdate=October 29, 2007}}</ref> Local governments may regulate smoking more stringently than the state.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.revisor.leg.state.mn.us/statutes/?id=144.417&year=2008 |title=Minn. Rev. Stat. § 144.417 |publisher=Revisor.leg.state.mn.us |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref> *[[Carlton County, Minnesota|Carlton County]], June 1, 2007, banned on 50% of outdoor patio seating in bars and restaurants.{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}} *[[Duluth, Minnesota|Duluth]], March 7, 2010, banned within {{convert|15|ft|m}} of a bus shelter or transit center.<ref>[http://www.duluthtransit.com/news/news.aspx?pid=1092 Duluthtransit.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101121122934/http://www.duluthtransit.com/news/news.aspx?pid=1092 |date=November 21, 2010}}</ref> *[[Golden Valley, Minnesota|Golden Valley]], March 31, 2009, banned within {{convert|25|ft|m}} of entrances, exits, and ventilation openings of all areas of bars and restaurants; also in public parks and recreational facilities.{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}} *[[Rochester, Minnesota|Rochester]], June 2010 Downtown smoke-free zone includes the block of Second Avenue Southwest between Gonda and the Kahler, and the two-block pedestrian mall known as the Peace Plaza. The zone was extended in June 2010 to include two blocks of West Center Street between the Kahler Grand Hotel, Methodist Hospital and the Gonda Building.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.postbulletin.com/newsmanager/templates/localnews_story.asp?z=2&a=453031 |title=Postbulletin.com |publisher=Postbulletin.com |accessdate=December 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20110103182513/http://www.postbulletin.com/newsmanager/templates/localnews_story.asp?z=2&a=453031 |archivedate=January 3, 2011 |df=mdy-all}}</ref>
===Mississippi=== *'''No statewide smoking ban.''' Instead, Mississippi's 2006 statewide smoking law, the Clean Indoor Air Act, prohibits smoking only inside any state or local government building (except designated areas in the state's veterans' homes) or inside any university or college classroom building.<ref>Miss. ===Missouri=== {{anchor|Missouri}} * '''No statewide smoking ban.''' Instead, Missouri's 1992 statewide smoking law, the Indoor Clean Air Act, prohibits smoking in all enclosed public places (including workplaces) and public meetings, except in designated smoking areas, which may occupy no more than 30% of the place's enclosed area.<ref name=morevstat191767>{{cite web |url=http://www.moga.mo.gov/statutes/C100-199/1910000767.HTM |title=Mo. Rev. Stat. § 191.767 |publisher=Moga.mo.gov |date=August 28, 2011 |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref> Warning signs must be appropriately posted either way.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.moga.mo.gov/statutes/C100-199/1910000771.HTM |title=Mo. Rev. Stat. § 191.771 |publisher=Moga.mo.gov |date=August 28, 2011 |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref> Local governments may prohibit smoking in schools, child daycare facilities, and school buses,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.moga.mo.gov/statutes/C100-199/1910000777.HTM |title=Mo. Rev. Stat. § 191.777 |publisher=Moga.mo.gov |date=August 28, 2011 |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref> as well as in public places.<ref name=morevstat191767/> Bars, restaurants that seat fewer than 50 people, bowling alleys, billiard parlors, retail tobacco shops, rooms and halls used for private social functions, limousines and taxicabs where the driver and all passengers agree to smoking, stage performances including smoking, indoor sports stadiums seating more than 15,000 people, and private residences "are not considered a public place".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://moga.mo.gov/statutes/C100-199/1910000769.HTM |title=Mo. Rev. Stat. § 191.769 |publisher=Moga.mo.gov |date=August 28, 2011 |accessdate=December 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111210110244/http://www.moga.mo.gov/statutes/C100-199/1910000769.HTM |archivedate=December 10, 2011 |df=mdy}}</ref> On June 23, 2009, the Western District of the [[Missouri Court of Appeals]] ruled that [[Kansas City, Missouri|Kansas City]]'s 2008 local ban on smoking in all workplaces, including bars and billiard parlors, did not conflict with this statute and was not [[federal preemption|preempted]].<ref name=kcbanappeal>[http://www.courts.mo.gov/file.asp?id=32827 ''City of Kansas City v. ===Montana=== *'''Statewide smoking ban''': On October 1, 2005, the Montana Clean Indoor Air Act (MCIAA) went into effect, banning smoking statewide in all enclosed workplaces in Montana including restaurants, though bars were exempt until October 1, 2009;<ref name=mca5040104>{{cite web |url=http://data.opi.state.mt.us/bills/mca/50/40/50-40-104.htm |title=Mont. Code Ann. § 50-40-104 |publisher= |accessdate=June 26, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090929223701/http://data.opi.state.mt.us/bills/mca/50/40/50-40-104.htm |archivedate=September 29, 2009 |df=mdy-all}}</ref> the word "bar" is defined in the Act as also including taverns, night clubs, cocktail lounges, and casinos.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://data.opi.state.mt.us/bills/mca/50/40/50-40-103.htm |title=§ 50-40-103 |publisher= |accessdate=June 26, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20031118024638/http://data.opi.state.mt.us/bills/mca/50/40/50-40-103.htm |archivedate=November 18, 2003 |df=mdy-all}}</ref> The act exempts private residences not used as a daycare facility or healthcare facility, private motor vehicles, tobacco demonstrations in schools, designated hotel/motel smoking rooms, and American Indian religious and cultural activities.<ref name=mca5040104/> Local governments are [[federal preemption|preempted]] from regulating smoking more stringently than the Act.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://data.opi.state.mt.us/bills/mca/50/40/50-40-120.htm |title=Mont. Code Ann. § 50-40-120 |publisher= |accessdate=June 26, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090929223658/http://data.opi.state.mt.us/bills/mca/50/40/50-40-120.htm |archivedate=September 29, 2009 |df=mdy-all}}</ref>
===Nebraska=== * '''Statewide smoking ban''': On June 1, 2009, the Nebraska Clean Indoor Air Act passed in February 2008 went into effect, banning smoking statewide in all enclosed workplaces in Nebraska, including all bars and restaurants.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://uniweb.legislature.ne.gov/laws/statutes.php?statute=71-5729 |title=N.R.S. § 71-5729 |publisher=Uniweb.legislature.ne.gov |accessdate=December 1, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029214636/http://uniweb.legislature.ne.gov/laws/statutes.php?statute=71-5729 |archivedate=October 29, 2013 |df=}}</ref> The Act exempts tobacco retail stores, designated hotel/motel smoking rooms, private residences, and places where scientific research about smoking is occurring.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://uniweb.legislature.ne.gov/laws/statutes.php?statute=71-5730 |title=N.R.S. § 71-5730 |publisher=Uniweb.legislature.ne.gov |accessdate=December 1, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029213530/http://uniweb.legislature.ne.gov/laws/statutes.php?statute=71-5730 |archivedate=October 29, 2013 |df=mdy-all}}</ref> In April 2009, the Act was amended to further exempt cigar bars, as well.<ref>[http://www.kcautv.com/Global/story.asp?S=10229934&nav=1kgl Associated Press, "Gov. signs cigar-bar exemption to Neb. smoking ban] ", KCAU-TV Sioux City, Iowa, April 22, 2009]</ref> Local governments may regulate smoking more stringently than the Act.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://uniweb.legislature.ne.gov/laws/statutes.php?statute=71-5717 |title=N.R.S. § 71-5717 |publisher=Uniweb.legislature.ne.gov |accessdate=December 1, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029214817/http://uniweb.legislature.ne.gov/laws/statutes.php?statute=71-5717 |archivedate=October 29, 2013 |df=mdy-all}}</ref>
===Nevada=== *'''Statewide smoking ban excluding bars, casinos, and designated restaurant smoking rooms''': On December 8, 2006, after passage by 54% of voters on November 7, 2006, the Nevada Clean Indoor Air Act went into effect, banning smoking statewide in all enclosed workplaces. The act passed by voters initially included all restaurants as well as bars that serve food.<ref name=nrs2022483>{{cite web |url=http://www.leg.state.nv.us/NRS/NRS-202.html#NRS202Sec2483 |title=NRS 202.2483 |publisher=Leg.state.nv.us |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref> The Act permits smoking without limitation in areas within casinos where minors are already prohibited, stand-alone bars that do not serve food, [[strip club]]s and [[brothel]]s, retail tobacco stores, and private residences (including those that serve as an office workplace, unless used as a childcare, adult daycare, or healthcare facility).<ref name=nrs2022483/> Local governments may regulate smoking more stringently than the Act,<ref name=nrs2022483/> though no city or county in Nevada has chosen to do so.<ref name=anrmunilist/> In 2009 Nevada partially repealed the ban to allow smoking in tobacco-related trade conventions.{{Citation needed|date=January 2010}} The ban was further amended in 2011 to allow smoking in taverns that serve alcohol and food as long as patrons under 21 are not allowed in. Smoking is also now allowed in designated areas of family restaurants if the smoking area is physically enclosed and separated from the non-smoking area and minors are prohibited inside.{{citation needed|date=May 2018}}
===New Hampshire=== *'''Statewide ban on smoking in bars, restaurants, and some other workplaces''': On September 17, 2007, the Indoor Smoking Act went into effect, banning smoking in schools, child daycare facilities, hospitals, grocery stores, elevators and public conveyances (except when rented for private purposes), restaurants, bars, and private clubs when open to the public.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gencourt.state.nh.us/rsa/html/XII/155/155-66.htm |title=N.H. Rev. Stat. Ann. § 155:66 |publisher=Gencourt.state.nh.us |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref> Private clubs and religious and fraternal organizations (including bars and restaurants inside these places), hotel and motel rooms, rented halls and rooms under control of the renter, college dormitory rooms, public housing, nursing homes, areas designated by hospitals, and alcohol/drug rehabilitation facilities are exempt from smoking regulation and can allow smoking indoors freely.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gencourt.state.nh.us/rsa/html/XII/155/155-67.htm |title=N.H. Rev. Stat. Ann. § 155:67 |publisher=Gencourt.state.nh.us |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref> All other places must designate smoking and nonsmoking areas and post appropriate signs.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gencourt.state.nh.us/rsa/html/XII/155/155-68.htm |title=N.H. Rev. Stat. Ann. § 155:68 |publisher=Gencourt.state.nh.us |date=January 1, 1991 |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref> On January 1, 2010, House Bill 392 went into effect. It established an on-premises cigar, beverage, and liquor license and allowed for cigar smoking at public cigar bars.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gencourt.state.nh.us/legislation/2009/HB0392.html |title=N.H. General Court, 829 A.2d 1089 (N.H. 2003) |publisher=Gencourt.state.nh.us |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref> Towns only can regulate smoking more strictly with regard to fire safety and sanitation.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gencourt.state.nh.us/rsa/html/XII/155/155-77.htm |title=N.H. Rev. Stat. Ann. § 155:67 |publisher=Gencourt.state.nh.us |date=January 1, 1991 |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref> In 2003, the [[New Hampshire Supreme Court]] ruled that this means state law [[federal preemption|preempts]] towns from enacting stricter local smoking bans for health reasons.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.courts.state.nh.us/supreme/opinions/2003/coleb111.htm |title=JTR Colebrook, Inc. v. Town of Colebrook, 829 A.2d 1089 (N.H. 2003) |publisher=Courts.state.nh.us |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref>
===New Jersey=== *'''Statewide smoking ban''': On April 15, 2006, the New Jersey Smoke-Free Air Act went into effect, banning smoking statewide in all enclosed workplaces in New Jersey, including all bars and restaurants, strip clubs, hospitals, psychiatric facilities, as well as outside portions of school grounds.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://lis.njleg.state.nj.us/cgi-bin/om_isapi.dll?clientID=149685&Depth=2&depth=2&expandheadings=on&headingswithhits=on&hitsperheading=on&infobase=statutes.nfo&record={A95E}&softpage=Doc_Frame_PG42 |title=N.J. Stat. § 26:3D-58 |publisher=Lis.njleg.state.nj.us |accessdate=December 2, 2011 }}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The Act exempts city parks, beaches, cigar bars, tobacco retail stores, tobacco manufacturing facilities, private residences and private automobiles, off-track betting parlors, and designated hotel/motel smoking rooms.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://lis.njleg.state.nj.us/cgi-bin/om_isapi.dll?clientID=149685&Depth=2&depth=2&expandheadings=on&headingswithhits=on&hitsperheading=on&infobase=statutes.nfo&record={A95E}&softpage=Doc_Frame_PG42 |title=N.J. Stat. § 26:3D-59 through 61 |publisher=Lis.njleg.state.nj.us |accessdate=December 2, 2011 }}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Local governments may regulate smoking more stringently than the Act.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://lis.njleg.state.nj.us/cgi-bin/om_isapi.dll?clientID=149685&Depth=2&depth=2&expandheadings=on&headingswithhits=on&hitsperheading=on&infobase=statutes.nfo&record={A95E}&softpage=Doc_Frame_PG42 |title=N.J. Stat. § 26:3D-63 |publisher=Lis.njleg.state.nj.us |accessdate=December 2, 2011 }}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Violating the Act can result in a fine of between $250 and $1,000, depending how many violations one has incurred within a year.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.state.nj.us/health/ctcp/smokefree/act.shtml |title=NJDOH - Smoke-free Air Act Initiative |publisher=State.nj.us |accessdate=January 14, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130126075012/http://www.state.nj.us/health/ctcp/smokefree/act.shtml |archivedate=January 26, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> *[[Atlantic City, New Jersey|Atlantic City]], banned in all enclosed workplaces, including bars and restaurants<ref name=anrmunilist/> as well as 75% of casino gaming floors.<ref>{{cite news |agency=[[Associated Press]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/10/28/nyregion/28ac.html |title=Atlantic City Suspends Casino Smoking Ban |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=October 27, 2008 |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref> *[[Pequannock, New Jersey|Pequannock]], banned in public parks with ball-fields or playgrounds in July 2011 through ordinance introduced by Mayor [[Rich Phelan]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.northjersey.com/news/125727693_Smoking_sanctions_floated_.html?page=all |title=Pequannock council reintroduces revamped smoking ban : page all |publisher=NorthJersey.com |date=July 18, 2011 |accessdate=December 1, 2013}}</ref> :See [[Smoke-Free Air Act]].
===New Mexico=== *'''Statewide smoking ban''': On June 15, 2007, the Dee Johnson Clean Indoor Air Act went into effect, banning smoking statewide in all enclosed workplaces in New Mexico, including all bars and restaurants, as well as within a "reasonable distance" of the entrances to those places.<ref>N.M. Stat. Ann. § 24-16-4</ref><ref>N.M. Stat. Ann. § 24-16-13</ref> The Act exempts (1) private residences except when being used to provide commercial childcare, adult care, and/or healthcare, (2) retail tobacco stores, (3) cigar bars, (4) tobacco manufacturing facilities, (5) casinos, (6) quit-smoking programs, (7) designated outdoor smoking areas, (8) private clubs, (9) limousines under private hire, (10) designated hotel/motel smoking rooms, (11) enclosed areas within restaurants, bars, and hotel/motel conference/meeting rooms that are being used for private functions, (12) cultural or ceremonial activities by American Indians, (13) non-bar/restaurant businesses with fewer than two employees that is not usually accessible to the public and all employees agree to allow smoking, and (14) stage, motion picture, or television productions involving smoking as part of the production.<ref>N.M. Stat. Ann. § 24-16-12</ref> Penalties are $100 for a first violation, $200 for a second violation within 12 months and $500 for the third and subsequent violations.<ref>N.M. Stat. Ann. § 24-16-18</ref> Local governments may regulate smoking more stringently than the Act.<ref>N.M. Stat. Ann. § 24-16-20</ref> UNM campuses are tobacco-free as of August 2009.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.unm.edu/smokefree/ |title=UNM.edu |publisher=UNM.edu |date=August 1, 2009 |accessdate=December 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120106225317/http://www.unm.edu/smokefree/ |archivedate=January 6, 2012 |df=mdy-all}}</ref>
===New York=== *'''Statewide smoking ban''': Effective July 24, 2003,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nyc.gov/html/doh/downloads/pdf/smoke/tc5.pdf |title=New York City Smoke-Free Air Act of 2002 |publisher=nyc.gov |accessdate=January 14, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121107072329/http://www.nyc.gov/html/doh/downloads/pdf/smoke/tc5.pdf |archivedate=November 7, 2012 |df=mdy-all}}</ref> smoking is banned statewide in all enclosed workplaces in New York, including all bars and restaurants and construction sites.<ref>N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 1399-O</ref> The law exempts (1) private homes and automobiles, (2) hotel/motel rooms, (3) retail tobacco businesses, (4) private clubs, (5) cigar bars (A cigar bar that makes 10 percent of its gross income from the on-site sale of tobacco products and the rental of on-site humidors, not including vending machines sales are exempt from the ban), (6) outdoor areas of bars and restaurants, and (7) enclosed rooms in restaurants, bars, convention halls, etc., when hosting private functions organized for the promotion and sampling of tobacco products.<ref name="N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 1399-Q">N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 1399-Q</ref> Local governments may regulate smoking more stringently than the state law.<ref>N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 1399-R</ref> Breaking the state law can result in a fine of between $200 and $2,000, depending how many violations one has had within a year.<ref name="N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 1399-Q"/> **[[Albany, New York|Albany]], On January 1, 2015, the following ordinance took effect. "No person shall smoke within the City's parks, sport fields, swimming pools, or playgrounds. For purposes of this section, to 'smoke' means to burn a lighted cigar, cigarette, or pipe or to use any other substance which contains tobacco."<ref>{{Cite web |title=City of Albany, NY Public Grounds Designated as Parks; Government and Care of Parks and Parkways |url=http://ecode360.com/7683565 |website=ecode360.com |accessdate=January 2, 2016}}</ref> **[[Great Neck (village), New York|Great Neck]], Adopted January 4, 2011, smoking was banned on sidewalks in front of commercial buildings, Village Green park, and the Housing Authority.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://abclocal.go.com/wabc/story?section=news/local/long_island&id=7883604 |title=Smoking ban enforced on Great Neck sidewalks | 7online.com |publisher=Abclocal.go.com |date=January 6, 2011 |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref> **[[New York City]], From May 18, 2014 everyone under the age of 21 was banned from buying cigarettes, tobacco products and e-cigarettes.<ref name="NYCban">{{cite news |title=Shops in New York told not to sell tobacco to under-21s |url=http://www.newyorkcitynews.net/index.php/sid/222099835/scat/5a8b8c26522de7fd/ht/Shops-in-New-York-told-not-to-sell-tobacco-to-under-21s |accessdate=May 19, 2014 |publisher=''New York City News.Net''}}</ref> Effective May 23, 2011, smoking was banned in all parks, boardwalks, beaches, recreation centers, swimming pools and pedestrian plazas.<ref>{{cite news |author=Ossad, Jordana |url=http://articles.cnn.com/2011-05-23/us/new.york.smoking.ban_1_smoking-on-public-beaches-smoking-ban-secondhand-smoke?_s=PM:US |title=New York City outdoor smoking ban begins. Archived. |publisher=CNN |date=May 23, 2011 |accessdate=January 14, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721122019/http://articles.cnn.com/2011-05-23/us/new.york.smoking.ban_1_smoking-on-public-beaches-smoking-ban-secondhand-smoke?_s=PM%3AUS |archivedate=July 21, 2011 |df=}}</ref> On March 30, 2003, smoking was banned in all enclosed workplaces, including bars and restaurants; exempts tobacco bars, owner-operated bars, separately ventilated smoking rooms in bars, private clubs with no employees, private functions organized for the promotion and sampling of tobacco products, and retail tobacco shops.<ref>2002 New York City Local Law No. 47</ref> Shortly after, on July 24, 2003, the statewide smoking ban came into effect. New York City may suspend or revoke a business's license if it has been found guilty of violating this law three times within 12 months.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nyc.gov/html/doh/html/smoke/tc1.shtml |title=Smoke-Free Air Act of 2002 : Tobacco Control : NYC DOHMH |publisher=Nyc.gov |accessdate=January 14, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121106200203/http://www.nyc.gov/html/doh///html/smoke/tc1.shtml |archivedate=November 6, 2012 |df=mdy-all}}</ref> On January 21, 1908, the [[New York City Council]] had passed the [[Sullivan Ordinance]], which would have banned women from smoking anywhere except their homes, but was vetoed by the [[Mayor of New York City|Mayor]] within two weeks of its passage.
===North Carolina=== *'''Statewide ban on smoking in bars, restaurants, and some other workplaces''': On January 2, 2010, after being signed into law by [[Governor of North Carolina|Governor]] [[Bev Perdue]] on May 19, 2009, North Carolina Session Law 2009-27 went into effect, banning smoking statewide in all bars and restaurants in North Carolina, as well as in government buildings and vehicles.<ref name=ncrestbarban>{{cite web |url=http://www.ncleg.net/Sessions/2009/Bills/House/PDF/H2v10.pdf |title=North Carolina Session Law 2009-27 |format=PDF |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref> The law exempts cigar bars, private clubs that are not-for-profit (including country clubs), designated hotel/motel smoking areas, and medical research facilities studying tobacco.<ref name=ncrestbarban/> The law generally allows local governments to regulate smoking more strictly beginning July 5, 2009 (as long as it is approved by the county, too), but [[federal preemption|preempts]] local governments from regulating smoking in cigar bars, retail tobacco shops, tobacco manufacturer facilities, designated hotel/motel smoking rooms, private clubs (including country clubs), theatrical productions involving smoking, private residences, or private vehicles.<ref name=ncrestbarban/> *'''Other statewide smoking regulation in North Carolina:''' **[[North Carolina Department of Correction]], January 2006, banned in all state prisons.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wral.com/news/local/story/1091350/ |title=Gas Tax, Prison Smoking Ban Among New State Laws, WRAL-TV, January 1, 2006 |publisher=Wral.com |date=January 1, 2006 |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref> **[[Orange County, North Carolina|Orange County]], January 1, 2012, banned on all sidewalks owned, operated, or maintained by the municipalities incorporated within the county. **[[UNC Health Care|UNC Hospitals]], August 2007, banned on all hospital grounds.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wral.com/news/news_briefs/story/1557002/ |title=Triangle Hospitals Ban Tobacco Use, WRAL-TV, July 3, 2007 |publisher=Wral.com |date=July 3, 2007 |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref> **[[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]], January 2008, banned on all university grounds except {{convert|100|ft|m}} from any school building.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ehs.unc.edu/healthy/smoking.shtml |title=Stay Healthy, UNC Department of Environment, Health & Safety |publisher=Ehs.unc.edu |accessdate=December 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110921063200/http://ehs.unc.edu/healthy/smoking.shtml |archivedate=September 21, 2011 |df=mdy-all}}</ref> **[[Waynesville, North Carolina|Waynesville]], May 23, 2015, banned on sidewalks, public parks, parking lots, greenways, city vehicles and the area in and surrounding town buildings<ref>{{cite web |title=WAYNESVILLE, N.C. SMOKING BAN PASSES |url=http://halfwheel.com/waynesville-n-c-smoking-ban-passes}}</ref>
===North Dakota=== *'''Statewide smoking ban''': On November 6, 2012, by a vote of 66%-34%, North Dakota voters ratified Initiative Measure Four, which, upon taking effect in December 2012, amends North Dakota's existing partial smoking ban so as to ban smoking statewide in all enclosed public places and places of employment, including all bars, restaurants, and tobacco stores.<ref>{{cite web |last=Van |first=Mara |url=http://bismarcktribune.com/news/state-and-regional/smoking-ban-to-change-bar-culture/article_3714c24c-292a-11e2-b86f-0019bb2963f4.html |title=Mara Van Ells, "Smoking ban to change bar culture," ''Bismarck Tribune'' (November 8, 2012) |publisher=Bismarcktribune.com |date=November 8, 2012 |accessdate=December 1, 2013}}</ref><ref name=ndban>{{cite web |url=https://vip.sos.nd.gov/pdfs/Portals/FullTextofMeasure4-Smoking-Nov6,2012.pdf |title=North Dakota Initiative Measure 4 (2012) |format=PDF |accessdate=December 1, 2013}}</ref> The ban exempts only (1) private residences except when operating as a childcare or adult day care facility, (2) outdoor areas except within 20 feet of the entrance to a public place or place of employment, (3) businesses not open to the public with no employees besides the owner, and (4) American Indian religious and cultural rituals.<ref name=ndban/> Local governments may regulate smoking more stringently than the state.<ref name=ndban/> As noted above, North Dakota is one of only six states that ban smoking in tobacco stores and is one of only four that prohibit hotels and motels from designating a certain percentage of rooms for smoking. **[[North Dakota State University]], 2008, banned outdoors on campus within {{convert|50|ft|m}} of buildings.{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}} **[[University of North Dakota]], [[Grand Forks, North Dakota|Grand Forks]], October 5, 2007, banned anywhere on campus grounds<ref>[http://www.dakotastudent.com/news/2008/11/21/News/Smoking.Ban.Shows.Positive.Results-3555473.shtml DakotaStudent.com: Smoking ban shows positive results] {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
===Northern Mariana Islands=== *'''Partial territory-wide smoking ban'''. Since September 29, 2009, smoking has been banned for most workplaces and restaurants, but not bars.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.no-smoke.org/goingsmokefree.php?id=655 |title=NMI |publisher=No-smoke.org |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref>
===Ohio=== *'''Statewide smoking ban''': On December 7, 2006, after passage by Ohio voters on November 7, 2006, Chapter 3794 (titled "Smoking Ban") of the [[Ohio Revised Code]] went into effect, banning smoking statewide in all enclosed workplaces in Ohio, including bars and restaurants.<ref name=ohioban>{{cite web |url=http://codes.ohio.gov/orc/3794 |title=Ohio Rev. Code Chapter 3794, "Smoking Ban" |publisher=Codes.ohio.gov |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref> The law exempts (1) private residences except when being used as a business when employees other than the owner are present, (2) designated hotel/motel smoking rooms, (3) family-owned and operated businesses not open to the public where all employees are related to the owner, (4) designated smoking areas in nursing homes, (5) retail tobacco stores, (6) outdoor patios, (7) private clubs with no employees.<ref name=ohioban/> The law is enforced by the Ohio Department of Health, which began enforcement on May 3, 2007.<ref name=ohioban/> A business may be fined up to $2,500 and individuals $100 for violation of the ban.<ref name=ohioban/> Local governments may regulate smoking more stringently than the state.<ref name=ohioban/> * A ruling by the 10th District Court of Appeals in Columbus upheld the law, stating that a bar owner had intentionally violated it. The bar owner, facing violations and fines totaling $33,000, brought suit, claiming the ban is unconstitutional. On May 23, 2012, The Supreme Court of Ohio affirmed the ruling of the Tenth District Court of Appeals.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.supremecourt.ohio.gov/PIO/summaries/2012/0523/110019.asp |title=Supreme Court of Ohio Case Summaries |publisher=Supremecourt.ohio.gov |accessdate=December 1, 2013}}</ref> * [[North Royalton, Ohio|North Royalton]], April 16, 2008, passed Ordinance 08-69 banning smoking in public outdoor places owned by the city. Smoking areas may be designated at the mayor's discretion.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.northroyalton.org/Council_Legislation_2008.htm |title=Council Legislation 2008 |publisher=Northroyalton.org |accessdate=December 1, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029194153/http://www.northroyalton.org/Council_Legislation_2008.htm |archivedate=October 29, 2013 |df=mdy-all}}</ref> * [[Oberlin, Ohio|Oberlin]], June 2010, Oberlin, banned smoking and the use of smokeless tobacco in city parks.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cityofoberlin.com/files/council%20clerk/ordinances/ordinance2010/ordinance_no._10-25_ac_cms.pdf |title=Cityofberlin.com |format=PDF |accessdate=December 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928142331/http://www.cityofoberlin.com/files/council%20clerk/ordinances/ordinance2010/ordinance_no._10-25_ac_cms.pdf |archivedate=September 28, 2011 |df=mdy-all}}</ref>
===Oklahoma=== *'''No statewide smoking ban.''' Instead, Oklahoma's statewide smoking law prohibits smoking in any indoor workplaces – including restaurants and hotels – unless a separate ventilation system under negative pressure is installed for ventilating the smoking area, but permits smoking without limitation in bars, private clubs, bingo halls, retail tobacco stores, small family-owned workplaces, workplaces occupied exclusively by smokers, veterans' halls, and designated employee smoking areas.<ref>Ok. Stat. Ann. Section 21-1247</ref><ref>Ok. Stat. Ann. Section 63-1-1523, ''et seq.''</ref> The Oklahoma law expressly [[federal preemption|preempts]] local governments from enacting any local smoking regulations that are not exactly the same as the state law.<ref>Ok. Stat. Ann. Section 63-1-1527</ref> In February 2009, a committee of the [[Oklahoma Senate]] '''rejected''' a proposed ban on smoking in all enclosed workplaces, including bars and restaurants, and a similar bill before the [[Oklahoma House of Representatives]] '''failed''' when it was denied a committee hearing.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tulsaworld.com/news/article.aspx?subjectid=16&articleid=20090219_16_0_OKLAHO599447 |title=Mick Hinton, "Committee waters down smoking bill", ''Tulsa World'', February 19, 2009 |publisher=Tulsaworld.com |date=February 19, 2009 |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref> In May 2009, a bill before the [[Oklahoma House of Representatives]] to repeal the preemption on stricter local smoking regulation '''failed''' when it did not receive a committee hearing.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://webserver1.lsb.state.ok.us/WebBillStatus/main.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051111232958/http://webserver1.lsb.state.ok.us/WebBillStatus/main.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=November 11, 2005 |title=Oklahom House Bill 1040 (2009) – status |publisher=Webserver1.lsb.state.ok.us |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref>
===Oregon=== *'''Statewide smoking ban''': Effective January 1, 2009, after being signed into law on June 26, 2007, the 1981 Oregon Indoor Clean Air Act (as previously amended in 2001) was amended to ban smoking statewide in all enclosed workplaces in Oregon, including bars and restaurants, as well as within {{convert|10|ft|m}} of the entrances, exits, or windows of such places.<ref>[http://landru.leg.state.or.us/ors/433.html Ore. Rev. Stat. § 433.845] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070314212606/http://landru.leg.state.or.us/ors/433.html|date=March 14, 2007}}</ref> The Act exempts (1) private residences except when serving as a childcare or adult care facility,<ref>[http://landru.leg.state.or.us/ors/433.html Ore. Rev. Stat. § 433.835] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070314212606/http://landru.leg.state.or.us/ors/433.html |date=March 14, 2007 }}</ref> (2) designated hotel/motel smoking rooms, (3) spaces designated for traditional American Indian religious and cultural ceremonies, (4) retail tobacco shops, and (5) cigar bars.<ref>[http://landru.leg.state.or.us/ors/433.html Ore. Rev. Stat. § 433.850] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070314212606/http://landru.leg.state.or.us/ors/433.html |date=March 14, 2007 }}</ref> Local governments may regulate smoking more stringently than the Act;<ref>[http://landru.leg.state.or.us/ors/433.html Ore. Rev. Stat. § 433.870] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070314212606/http://landru.leg.state.or.us/ors/433.html |date=March 14, 2007 }}</ref> and the [[Oregon Court of Appeals]] reiterated this in 2000.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.publications.ojd.state.or.us/A101883.htm |title=Oregon Restaurant Ass'n v. City of Corvallis, 166 Ore. App. 506, 999 P.2d 518 (2000) |publisher=Publications.ojd.state.or.us |accessdate=December 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120106131957/http://www.publications.ojd.state.or.us/A101883.htm |archivedate=January 6, 2012 |df=mdy-all}}</ref>
===Pennsylvania=== * '''Statewide smoking ban excluding bars, casinos and some restaurants'''. Effective September 11, 2008, after being signed into law by [[Governor of Pennsylvania|Governor]] [[Ed Rendell]] on June 13, 2008, Pennsylvania's 1988 Clean Indoor Air Act was amended to ban smoking statewide in all restaurants and other enclosed workplaces in Pennsylvania, except as exempted.<ref name=pa2008ban>{{cite web |url=http://www.legis.state.pa.us/CFDOCS/Legis/PN/Public/btCheck.cfm?txtType=PDF&sessYr=2007&sessInd=0&billBody=S&billTyp=B&billNbr=0246&pn=2099 |title=2008 Pennsylvania Senate Bill 246 |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref> The Act exempts (1) eating/drinking establishments where 20% or less of sales come from food AND persons under 18 are not allowed, (2) private homes and vehicles, except those used as a child daycare or adult care facility, (3) designated hotel/motel smoking rooms, (4) full service truck stops, (5) retail tobacco shops, (6) workplaces of tobacco manufacturers and wholesalers, (7) nursing homes, (8) designated smoking areas in day treatment facilities, psychiatric facilities, and healthcare facilities, (9) private clubs when public events are not being held, including volunteer fire, ambulance, and rescue stations, (10) tobacco-related fundraisers, (11) places rented for tobacco exhibitions, (12) cigar bars, (13) 25% of a casino gaming floor, and (14) outdoor areas.<ref name=pa2008banlaw>{{cite web |url=http://www.legis.state.pa.us/WU01/LI/LI/US/HTM/2008/0/0027..HTM |title=Act of Jun. 13, 2008, P.L. 182, No. 27 Cl. 35 – CLEAN INDOOR AIR ACT – ENACTMENT |accessdate=September 12, 2012}}</ref> Local governments except [[Philadelphia]] are [[federal preemption|preempted]] from regulating smoking more stringently than the Act.<ref name=pa2008banlaw/> Philadelphia's smoking ordinance, which went into effect on January 8, 2007, bans smoking in all restaurants, exempting bars where food accounts for less than 10% of sales and alcohol accounts for more than 90% of sales, and persons under 18 are prohibited.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.smokefreephilly.org/clean_air_laws.cfm |title=Philadelphia Smoking Ban |publisher=Smokefreephilly.org |accessdate=December 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130415204221/http://www.smokefreephilly.org/clean_air_laws.cfm |archivedate=April 15, 2013 |df=mdy-all}}</ref> Philadelphia's ordinance is the only local smoking ban in Pennsylvania.<ref name=anrmunilist/> On April 29, 2014, Mayor Michael Nutter passed an executive order banning smoking in all city parks.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nbcphiladelphia.com/news/politics/Smoking-Ban-Philadelphia-257125421.html |title=Nutter to Ban Smoking in Philly Parks |work=NBC 10 Philadelphia |accessdate=December 25, 2015}}</ref> Allegheny County enacted a smoking ban October 2006, but it was immediately challenged in court as violating the 1988 Clean Indoor Air Act's preemption of all local smoking regulations.<ref name=ward>{{cite news |last=Ward |first=Paula Reed |author2=Anita Srikameswaran |title=County's smoking ban in ashes |newspaper=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]] |date=May 22, 2007 |url=http://www.post-gazette.com/stories/local/uncategorized/countys-smoking-ban-in-ashes-486167/ |accessdate=September 9, 2012}}</ref> In May 2007, the ban was overturned by the [[Pennsylvania Commonwealth Court]].<ref name=ward /> * '''<nowiki/>'Smoking-Free Beaches' Program:''' Pennsylvania's 'Smoke-Free Beaches' program was initiated by the Pennsylvania Department of Conservation and Natural Resources. This program places smoking constraints at designated parks to eliminate smoking on beaches and swimming areas. For visitors who smoke and still want to use these beaches, designated areas adjacent to the beach are provided. The restriction includes cigarettes, pipes, cigars and the increasingly popular [[e-cigarettes]]. Staff at newly affected parks have been preparing for the change by purchasing and installing butt disposal units; installing new signage; establishing designated smoking areas with seating; and informing park user and support groups. ** In 2016, 12 state parks initiated new "Smoke Free Beaches." They were: Hills Creek, Tioga County; Lyman Run, Potter County; R.B. Winter, Union; Presque Isle, Erie; Pymatuning, Crawford, Laurel Hill, Somerset County; Whipple Dam, Huntingdon County; Gifford Pinchot, York County; Cowans Gap, Fulton County; Gouldsboro, Monroe County; Ricketts Glen, Luzerne County; and Worlds End, Sullivan.
===Puerto Rico=== *'''Territory-wide smoking ban:''' Effective March 2, 2007, smoking is banned territory-wide in all enclosed workplaces in Puerto Rico, including bars and restaurants, as well as private vehicles when either a minor in a car seat or a child under 13 is present.<ref>{{cite web |author=NextPage – LivePublish |url=http://www.michie.com/puertorico/lpext.dll/prcode/15fe1/16870/16ac2/16ac9?f=templates&fn=document-frame.htm&2.0#JD_24892 |title=P.R. Laws ch. 62 § 892 |publisher=Michie.com |date=December 19, 2002 |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref> The law exempts (1) retail tobacco stores, (2) theater and film productions and presentations in which actors smoke as part of their character, (3) private homes except when serving as a workplace, and (4) designated hotel/motel smoking rooms.<ref>{{cite web |author=NextPage – LivePublish |url=http://www.michie.com/puertorico/lpext.dll/prcode/15fe1/16870/16ac2/16ad3?f=templates&fn=document-frame.htm&2.0#JD_24894 |title=P.R. Laws ch. 62 § 894 |publisher=Michie.com |date=December 19, 2002 |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref>
===Rhode Island=== *'''Statewide smoking ban''': On March 1, 2005, the Public Health and Workplace Safety Act went into effect, banning smoking statewide in all enclosed workplaces in Rhode Island, including bars and restaurants.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rilin.state.ri.us/Statutes/TITLE23/23-20.10/23-20.10-3.HTM |title=R.I. Gen. Laws § 23-20.10-3 |publisher=Rilin.state.ri.us |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rilin.state.ri.us/Statutes/TITLE23/23-20.10/23-20.10-4.HTM |title=R.I. Gen. Laws § 23-20.10-4 |publisher=Rilin.state.ri.us |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref> The Act exempts (1) cigar bars (income over 50% tobacco products), (2) outdoor areas, (3) private and semiprivate rooms in nursing homes, (4) retail tobacco stores, (5) stage performances involving smoking, (6) private residences, except used as a licensed child care, adult daycare, or healthcare facility,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rilin.state.ri.us/Statutes/TITLE23/23-20.10/23-20.10-6.HTM |title=R.I. Gen. Laws § 23-20.10-6 |publisher=Rilin.state.ri.us |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref> and (7) the two state-licensed gambling facilities, Newport Grand and [[Twin River Casino]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rilin.state.ri.us/Statutes/TITLE23/23-20.10/23-20.10-6.1.HTM |title=R.I. Gen. Laws § 23-20.10–6.1 |publisher=Rilin.state.ri.us |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref> Local governments may regulate smoking more strictly than the Act,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rilin.state.ri.us/Statutes/TITLE23/23-20.10/23-20.10-13.HTM |title=R.I. Gen. Laws § 23-20.10–13 |publisher=Rilin.state.ri.us |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref> though as of April 2009 none have chosen to do so.<ref name=anrmunilist/>
===South Carolina=== * '''No statewide smoking ban.''' Instead, South Carolina's 1990 statewide smoking law, the Clean Indoor Air Law, generally prohibits smoking only in (1) public schools, excluding offices and teacher lounges (unless a local school board says otherwise), (2) childcare facilities, (3) healthcare facilities, except in designated employee smoking areas (unless the facilities chooses to be smoke-free), (4) government buildings, except in designated employee smoking areas (and except the State Capitol and legislative office buildings), (5) elevators, (6) public transportation vehicles, and (7) public theatres and arenas, except in designated smoking areas in common areas,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.scstatehouse.gov/code/t44c095.htm |title=S.C. Code § 44-95-20 |publisher=Scstatehouse.gov |date=December 31, 1990 |accessdate=December 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111124194703/http://scstatehouse.gov/code/t44c095.htm |archivedate=November 24, 2011 |df=mdy-all}}</ref> and in any such designated smoking area warning signs must be appropriately posted.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.scstatehouse.gov/code/t44c095.htm |title=S.C. Code § 44-95-30 |publisher=Scstatehouse.gov |date=December 31, 1990 |accessdate=December 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111124194703/http://scstatehouse.gov/code/t44c095.htm |archivedate=November 24, 2011 |df=mdy-all}}</ref> The Act covers no other places. ===South Dakota=== *'''Statewide smoking ban''': South Dakota voters passed 2009 H.B. 1240 on November 10, 2010. The bill bans smoking statewide in all enclosed workplaces in South Dakota, including bars and restaurants,<ref name=sdban>{{citation |url=http://www.sdtobaccofree.org/Portals/Site1/HB1240P.pdf |title=2009 South Dakota H.B. 1240 |publisher=South Dakota Tobacco-Free Kids Network |year=2010 |accessdate=November 24, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110728010438/http://www.sdtobaccofree.org/Portals/Site1/HB1240P.pdf |archivedate=July 28, 2011 |df=mdy-all}}</ref> exempting only private residences unless used for child daycare,<ref name=sdban/> cigar bars, retail tobacco shops, and a percentage of hotel and motel rooms.<ref>[http://www.mitchellrepublic.com/ap/index.cfm?page=view&id=D9716JE80 Associated Press: "Governor signs ban on smoking in bars, casinos", ''Mitchell (S.D.) Daily Republic'', March 19, 2009] {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> The bill was passed in the [[South Dakota State Legislature]] and signed into law by [[Governor of South Dakota|Governor]] [[Mike Rounds]]. It was scheduled to take effect in July 2009, but on June 22, 2009, a group of casino and video lottery operators presented the [[Secretary of State of South Dakota|Secretary of State]] with a petition for a referendum over H.B. 1240 that they claimed to bear 25,000 valid signatures.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mitchellrepublic.com/event/apArticle/id/D98VSIMG0/ |title=Chet Brokaw, "Petitions filed to put SD smoking ban to vote," ''Mitchell (S.D.) Daily Republic'', June 22, 2009 |publisher=Mitchellrepublic.com |accessdate=December 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130411092733/http://www.mitchellrepublic.com/event/apArticle/id/D98VSIMG0/ |archivedate=April 11, 2013 |df=mdy-all}}</ref> On June 25, 2009, the Secretary of State certified that the petition indeed bore at least the required 16,776 valid signatures, putting H.B. 1240 to the November 2010 public referendum.<ref>[http://www.argusleader.com/article/20090626/NEWS/906260326/1001/news Steve Young, "Petitions get OK in smoking fight", ''Sioux Falls Argus Leader'', June 25, 2009]{{dead link|date=December 2011}}</ref> On July 24, 2009, the Secretary of State declared that after further review, the number of valid signatures on the petition fell short of the required number to put the issue on the ballot.<ref>[http://www.argusleader.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20090724/NEWS/907240331 Smoking Ban Clears Big Hurdle]{{dead link|date=December 2011}}</ref> On November 13, 2009, however, Circuit Judge Kathleen Trandahl ruled that the petition ''did'' have enough valid signatures, and ordered the Secretary of State to put the issue to a public vote on November 2, 2010,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://keloland.com/NewsDetail6162.cfm?Id=92683 |title=Voters Will Decide On Smoking Ban |publisher=Keloland TV |date=November 13, 2009 |accessdate=November 24, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713142944/http://keloland.com/NewsDetail6162.cfm?Id=92683 |archivedate=July 13, 2011 |df=mdy-all}}</ref> which ultimately passed. H.B. 1240 is silent as to whether local governments may regulate smoking more stringently, though as of November 2010 no local governments in South Dakota have done so.
===Tennessee=== *'''No statewide smoking ban.''' Instead, Tennessee's 2007 statewide smoking law, the Non-Smoker Protection Act, prohibits smoking statewide in all public places in Tennessee, except as exempted;<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.michie.com/tennessee/lpext.dll/tncode/11660/1207c/12547/1255e?f=templates&fn=document-frame.htm&2.0#JD_39-17-1803 |title=T.C.A. § 39-17-1803 |publisher=Michie.com |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref> (1) any business, including a bar or restaurant, that does not serve persons under 21, (2) designated hotel/motel smoking rooms, (3) tobacco industry-related facilities, (4) outdoor areas and areas with an open garage door, (5) nursing homes, (6) designated smoking areas not accessible to the general public in businesses with three or fewer employees, (7) private clubs, (8) private residences and vehicles unless it is being used for child care, daycare, or public transportation of children, (9) retail tobacco stores, and (10) commercial vehicles occupied solely by the operator.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.michie.com/tennessee/lpext.dll/tncode/11660/1207c/12547/12563?f=templates&fn=document-frame.htm&2.0#JD_39-17-1804 |title=T.C.A. § 39-17-1803 |publisher=Michie.com |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref> Local governments are [[federal preemption|preempted]] from regulating smoking.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.protectlocalcontrol.org/state.php?sid=43 |title=Protectlocalcontrol.org |publisher=Protectlocalcontrol.org |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref>
===Texas=== *'''No statewide smoking ban.''' Instead, Texas' 1997 statewide smoking law only prohibits smoking in activities of public schools on or off school property,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.statutes.legis.state.tx.us/SOTWDocs/ED/htm/ED.38.htm#38.006 |title=Tex. Educ. Code § 38.006 |publisher=Statutes.legis.state.tx.us |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref> elevators, theatres, libraries, museums, hospitals, buses, airplanes, and trains, as long as these areas are open to the general public, unless the proprietor designates the place for smoking and posts appropriate warning signs.<ref name=tex4801>{{cite web |url=http://www.statutes.legis.state.tx.us/SOTWDocs/PE/htm/PE.48.htm#48.01 |title=Tex. Penal Code § 48.01 |publisher=Statutes.legis.state.tx.us |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref> Violation of this law is a class C misdemeanor.<ref name=tex4801/> Texas law is silent as to whether local governments may regulate smoking more stringently than the state, and on December 9, 2004, the [[Texas Courts of Appeals|Texas Court of Appeals]] upheld [[El Paso, Texas|El Paso]]'s municipal ban on smoking in all bars and restaurants.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?q=smoking+ordinance&hl=en&as_sdt=4,44&case=9142854809925344402&scilh=0 |title=Google Scholar ===Utah=== *'''Statewide smoking ban''': Effective January 1, 2007, as passed in March 2006 (amended in 2012),<ref>{{cite web |url=http://le.utah.gov/code/TITLE26/htm/26_38_000206.htm |title=U.C.A. 1953 § 26-38-2.6 |publisher=[[Government of Utah|Utah State]] |accessdate=March 12, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130208040907/http://le.utah.gov/code/TITLE26/htm/26_38_000206.htm |archivedate=February 8, 2013 |df=mdy-all}}</ref> Utah's 1995 Indoor Clean Air Act was expanded to ban smoking statewide in all enclosed workplaces in Utah, including bars and restaurants (bars and private clubs were exempt until January 1, 2009), exempting only (1) designated hotel/motel smoking rooms, (2) areas of owner-operated businesses with no employees besides the owner,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://le.utah.gov/~code/TITLE26/htm/26_38_000300.htm |title=U.C.A. 1953 § 26-38-3 |publisher=[[Government of Utah|Utah State]] |accessdate=December 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120106064020/http://le.utah.gov/~code/TITLE26/htm/26_38_000300.htm |archivedate=January 6, 2012 |df=mdy-all}}</ref> and (3) American Indian religious and cultural ceremonies.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://le.utah.gov/~code/TITLE26/htm/26_38_000305.htm |title=U.C.A. 1953 § 26-38-3.5 |publisher=[[Government of Utah|Utah State]] |accessdate=December 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120106083456/http://le.utah.gov/~code/TITLE26/htm/26_38_000305.htm |archivedate=January 6, 2012 |df=mdy-all}}</ref> Since the state law supersedes any ordinances passed by political subdivisions of the state (i.e., cities, counties, school districts, agencies, etc.), such political subdivisions are preempted from regulating ''indoor'' smoking any more or less stringently than the Act.<ref name="UCA 26-38-6">{{cite web |url=http://le.utah.gov/~code/TITLE26/htm/26_38_000600.htm |title=U.C.A. 1953 § 26-38-6 |publisher=[[Government of Utah|Utah State]] |accessdate=March 12, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120928013904/http://le.utah.gov/~code/TITLE26/htm/26_38_000600.htm |archivedate=September 28, 2012 |df=mdy-all}}</ref> Utah is one of the few states with a statewide smoking ban that does not exempt [[tobacconist]]s. **''Local outdoor smoking bans'': Notwithstanding the preemption against political subdivisions modifying the restrictions on ''indoor'' smoking, the Act expressly allows such political subdivisions to regulate "smoking in ''outdoor'' places of public access which are owned or operated by" (emphasis added) a political subdivision (specifically including state institutions of public or higher education).<ref name="UCA 26-38-6"/> Accordingly, some political subdivisions have enacted local ordinances prohibiting smoking in certain outdoor areas such as schools, parks,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.utahcountyonline.org/Dept/Health/smokefree/2008utdoorSmokingRegJuly10.pdf |title=Utah County Board of Health Regulation on Smoking in Outdoor Public Places |publisher=Utah County Health Department |accessdate=March 12, 2013}}</ref> and public transit facilities.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rideuta.com/mc/?page=RidingUTA-RiderRules |title=Rider Rules |publisher=[[Utah Transit Authority]] |accessdate=March 12, 2013}}</ref>
===Vermont=== *'''Statewide smoking ban''': Effective September 1, 2005, smoking is banned in all enclosed workplaces in Vermont, including all bars and restaurants,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.leg.state.vt.us/statutes/fullsection.cfm?Title=18&Chapter=037&Section=01742 |title=Ver. Stat. tit. 28 § 1742 |publisher=Leg.state.vt.us |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref> except in areas of owner-operated businesses with no employees that are not open to the public,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.leg.state.vt.us/statutes/fullsection.cfm?Title=18&Chapter=037&Section=01743 |title=Ver. Stat. tit. 28 § 1743 |publisher=Leg.state.vt.us |date=September 1, 2005 |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref> although separately ventilated designated smoking areas in businesses where employees are not required to be were exempt until July 1, 2009.<ref name=vtnewban>{{cite web |url=http://www.timesargus.com/article/20090530/NEWS01/905300350/1002/NEWS01 |title=Daniel Barlow, "Workplace smoking ban starts July 1", ''The Barre Montpelier Times Argus'', May 30, 2009 |publisher=Timesargus.com |date=May 30, 2009 |accessdate=December 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151117032131/http://www.timesargus.com/article/20090530/NEWS01/905300350/1002/NEWS01 |archivedate=November 17, 2015 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Designated unenclosed smoking areas in businesses where the layout of the workplace is such that smoking would not be a physical irritation to any nonsmoking employee and three-fourths of the employees agreed were also exempt until July 1, 2009.<ref name=vtnewban/> The Vermont Veterans Home in [[Bennington, Vermont|Bennington]] is the only non-owner-operated workplace in the state permitted to allow smoking.<ref name=vtnewban/> Vermont is one of the few states with a statewide smoking ban that does not expressly exempt [[tobacconist]]s, and is one of four states that does not allow the designation of hotel/motel smoking rooms. Local governments may regulate smoking more stringently than the state law.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.leg.state.vt.us/statutes/fullsection.cfm?Title=18&Chapter=028&Section=01428 |title=Ver. Stat. tit. 28 § 1428 |publisher=Leg.state.vt.us |date=July 1, 1988 |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.leg.state.vt.us/statutes/fullsection.cfm?Title=18&Chapter=037&Section=01746 |title=Ver. Stat. tit. 28 § 1746 |publisher=Leg.state.vt.us |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref>

===Virginia=== *'''No statewide smoking ban.''' Instead, Virginia's 2009 statewide smoking law, the 2009 Indoor Clean Air Act prohibits smoking statewide in enclosed public elevators, public school buses, primary and secondary schools, hospital emergency rooms, health department offices, polling places, indoor service lines and cashier lines, public restrooms in government buildings and hospitals, child daycare centers except where located in a private home, and public restrooms of health care facilities, and relegating smoking in restaurants (including bars) to separately ventilated designated smoking rooms that are structurally separated from the rest of the establishment.<ref name=vaban>{{cite web |url=http://leg1.state.va.us/cgi-bin/legp504.exe?091+ful+SB1105S2 |title=Va. Senate Bill 1105 (2009) |publisher=Leg1.state.va.us |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Davis |first=Chelyen |url=http://www.fredericksburg.com/local/house-senate-ok-smoke-ban/article_2214b83b-97f4-573b-ab73-8362f48ec745.html |title=Chelyen Davis, "House, Senate OK smoke ban," ''The Fredericksburg (Va.) Free Lance-Star'', February 20, 2009 |publisher=Fredericksburg.com |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref> The Act exempts private clubs, retail tobacco stores, tobacco warehouses, tobacco manufacturing facilities, prisons, designated smoking areas in government offices, food preparation facilities for catering services, restaurants located on the premises of tobacco manufacturers, rented private rooms in restaurants; requires the reasonable designation of non-smoking areas in educational facilities where smoking is not banned, hospitals, retail stores bigger than {{convert|15000|sqft|m2}}, and recreational facilities.<ref name=vaban/>
Local governments are [[federal preemption|preempted]] from regulating smoking more stringently than the Act.<ref name=vaban/> Effectively, the cost and complexity involved with complying with the law's requirements for separately ventilated smoking areas has meant that nearly all Virginia bars and restaurants operate completely smoke-free. Since 2006, smoking in state offices, vehicles, and buildings (except for correctional facilities) has been banned by executive order issued by the [[Governor of Virginia]].<ref>[http://www.governor.virginia.gov/initiatives/ExecutiveOrders/2006/EO_41.cfm Banning Smoking in State Offices and Vehicles (Virginia Executive Order)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029203840/http://www.governor.virginia.gov/initiatives/ExecutiveOrders/2006/EO_41.cfm |date=October 29, 2013}}</ref> A law which came into effect on July 1, 2016 banned smoking in private cars with any occupants who are 8 years or younger.<ref>[http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/USA-Update/2016/0629/Virginia-bans-smoking-in-cars-with-children-eight-or-younger Virginia bans smoking in cars with children eight or younger]</ref> In December 2013, the [[Court of Appeals of Virginia]] held 100% of the premises of a retail tobacco store that also operates a restaurant is exempt from Virginia's 2009 smoking restrictions, and may allow smoking throughout the restaurant portion.<ref>''Kepa, Inc. v. Va. Dept. of Health'', 751 S.E.2d 671 (Va. App. 2013)</ref> **[[Norfolk, Virginia|Norfolk]], March 25, 2008, '''repealed''' a ban on smoking in restaurants, which was passed in October 2007 but had not yet gone into effect, by City Council vote of 5–2, because the City Attorney advised the Council that its ban would violate Virginia state law and could not withstand a legal challenge.<ref>{{cite web |last=Minium |first=Harry |url=http://hamptonroads.com/2008/03/norfolk-council-reverses-itself-smoking-ban#comment-600808 |title=Harry Minium, "Norfolk council reverses itself on smoking ban", ''The Virginian-Pilot'', March 26, 2008 |publisher=Hamptonroads.com |date=March 26, 2008 |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref>

===Wisconsin=== * '''Statewide smoking ban''': On July 5, 2009, after being signed into law by [[Governor of Wisconsin|Governor]] [[Jim Doyle]] on May 18, 2009, S.B. 181 (2009 Wisconsin Act 12) took effect, banning smoking statewide in all enclosed workplaces in Wisconsin, including all bars, restaurants, lodging establishments, and private clubs, as well as within a "reasonable distance" outdoors from any such place, except in bar/restaurant outdoor patios.<ref name=wiban>{{cite web |url=http://www.legis.state.wi.us/2009/data/SB-181.pdf |title=2009 Wisconsin Senate Bill 181 |format=PDF |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref> The Act exempts only cigar bars or retail tobacco stores already in existence, private residences, and rooms in nursing homes in which the occupants agree to allow smoking; it does not cover casinos run by American Indian tribes, as those casinos are in the tribes' sovereign territory.<ref name=wiban/> Local governments are [[federal preemption|preempted]] from regulating smoking more strictly than the Act.<ref name=wiban/> Prior to this law taking effect, several localities in Wisconsin had local smoking bans in effect. <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.smokersclubinc.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=2198 |title=Statewide smoking ban picks up steam, ''Green Bay Press Gazette'', April 9, 2006 |publisher=Smokersclubinc.com |date=March 5, 2006 |accessdate=December 2, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120106094938/http://www.smokersclubinc.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=2198 |archive-date=January 6, 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref>

== Smoking related damages in the United States ==
=== Slow Decomposition of Cigarettes === In the United States alone there over 176,000,000 pounds of discarded cigarette butts per year. Research has shown that cigarettes pose an extremely large threat to the environment and our wildlife. Cigarettes contain small amounts of plastic that cannot naturally decompose. A study published in 2015 showed that after two years only 38% of a cigarette butt decomposes. In addition to cigarette butt's long composition time, the chemicals found within cigarette filters can remain in the soil for up to 10 years. The problem created by cigarettes affects natural resources across the United States and poses a serious threat to the diverse wildlife population within it.
=== Forest Fires and Property Damage from Cigarettes === In addition to the pollution from cigarettes, the National Fire Protection Agency has concluded that smoking materials like cigarettes, pipes, and cigars, directly cause 90,000 fires per year in the United States. These smoking related fires cause over 27 billion dollars per year.
