{{Infobox medical person |name = Paul M. Ellwood Jr. |image = |image_size = |alt = |caption = |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1926|07|16}} |birth_place = [[San Francisco]], [[California]] |death_date = |death_place = |profession = |specialism = [[pediatrics|pediatric]] [[neurologist]] |research_field = |known_for = Creator of [[Health maintenance organization|HMO]]s |years_active = |education = |work_institutions = |prizes = |relations = |signature = }} '''Paul M. Ellwood Jr.''' (born 16 July 1926) is a prominent figure in [[Health care in the United States|American health care]]. Often referred to as the "[[father of]] the [[health maintenance organization]],"<ref>See, for instance, {{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/02/28/business/hillary-clinton-s-potent-brain-trust-on-health-reform.html |first=Robin |last=Toner |title=Hillary Clinton’s Potent Brain Trust on Health Reform |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=February 28, 1993 |page=Section 3, p. 1}} and Michael Booth, "The Latest from the Father of the HMO," Corporate Report Minnesota, Cover Story, October 1991.</ref><ref>In [http://www.managedcaremag.com/archives/9711/9711.qnaellwood.html "New Optimism from the Father of the HMO, An Interview with Paul Ellwood Jr., MD," Managed Care (November 1997)], Ellwood reports he coined the term in May 1970 for the Nixon Administration.</ref> he not only coined the term, he also played a role in bringing about structural changes to the [[American health care system]] to simultaneously control cost and promote health by replacing [[fee-for-service]] with prepaid, comprehensive care.<ref>{{cite book |last=Starr |first=Paul |authorlink=Paul Starr |url=https://books.google.com/?id=FK4pBXGvQzoC&vq=%22The+Social+Transformation+Of+American+Medicine%22+Basic+Books |title=The Social Transformation of American Medicine |location=New York |publisher=Basic Books |year=1982 |page=395 |isbn=0-465-07935-0}}</ref> The term "HMO" was coined by Dr. Paul M. Ellwood Jr. in a January 1970 Fortune Magazine article.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Our Ailing Medical System: It's Time to Operate |journal=Fortune Magazine |date=January 1970 |publisher=New York, Harper & Row}}</ref><ref>{{cite report |author=U.S. Congress, Office of Technology Assessment |title=Managed Care and Competitive Health Care Markets: the Twin Cities Experience |publisher=U.S. Government Printing Office |date=July 1994 |location=Washington, DC |id=OTA-BP-H- 130 |url=http://ota.fas.org/reports/9419.pdf}}</ref> More recently, he has advanced an agenda for monitoring health outcomes, so that patients, providers, and payers can make health care decisions based on real information about what treatments and providers are actually effective.
Ellwood began his career as a [[pediatrics|pediatric]] [[neurologist]], specializing in [[polio]] at the height of the [[History of poliomyelitis|international polio epidemic]] in the early 1950s. The epidemic subsided with the introduction of the [[polio vaccine]] by [[Jonas Salk]]. The [[Elizabeth Kenny|Sister Kenny Institute]], which Ellwood directed, then filled its vacant beds with children suffering from [[learning disabilities]]. According to Ellwood, one evening while doing rounds amid crying children, it struck him that they were making decisions for economic reasons (the need to fill hospital beds) that were not in the best interests of patients. His growing conviction that this calculus – putting the interests of health care providers over patient well-being – characterized the American medical system in general, led him to conceive of and advocate for alternative approaches.<ref name="aha"/>
==Biography== Ellwood was born on July 16, 1926 in [[San Francisco]]<ref name="aha"/><ref name="who">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/?id=Zk9rAAAAMAAJ&dq=paul+m.+ellwood+jr.+kenny+institute+1953+1971&q=ellwood |title=Who's Who in Health Care |publisher=Hanover Publications |year=1981 |page=136}}</ref> and raised in [[Oakland, California]]. He was the son of a nurse-turned-homemaker and a dedicated physician who made house calls much of Paul’s young life and served inner-city patients in Oakland into his eighties.<ref name="pmid11698912">{{Cite journal |last1=Ellwood Jr |first1=P. M. |title=Does managed care need to be replaced? |journal=MedGenMed : Medscape general medicine |volume=3 |issue=5 |pages=5 |year=2001 |pmid=11698912 |url=http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/408185}}</ref> After graduating high school, Ellwood enlisted in the [[United States Navy|Navy]] and served as Pharmacist Mate Third Class in the [[Philippines]]<ref name="aha">{{cite web |url=http://www.aha.org/research/rc/chhah/Ellwood--FINAL--050211.pdf |title=Paul M. Elwood Jr., M.D. In First Person: An Oral History |last=Kovner |first=Anthony R. |publisher=American Hospital Association Center |date=16 September 2010 |accessdate=5 February 2012}}</ref> from 1944 to 1946. He went on to earn a bachelor's degree from [[Stanford University]] in 1949 and a medical degree from [[Stanford Medical School]] in 1953.<ref name="who"/> He worked in the Elizabeth Kenny Institute, later known as the American Rehabilitation Foundation, from 1953 to 1971, as a physician and ultimately the Executive Director. At the same time he served as Clinical Professor of [[Pediatrics]], [[Neurology]] and [[Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation]] at the [[University of Minnesota]], where he founded the program in Pediatric Neurology.<ref name="Q&A">{{cite journal |url=http://journals.lww.com/neurotodayonline/Fulltext/2001/11000/Q__A_With_Paul_Ellwood,_Jr_,_MD__Father_of_Managed.18.aspx |journal=Neurology Today |volume=1 |issue=4 |page=36 |last=Elming |first=Shelley |title=Q &A With Paul Ellwood Jr., MD 'Father of Managed Competition Concept' |date=November–December 2001 |doi=10.1097/00132985-200111000-00018}}</ref> He was co-editor of the ''Handbook of Physical Medicine'',<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Handbook_of_physical_medicine_and_rehabi.html?id=BgjOjwEACAAJ |title=Handbook of physical medicine and rehabilitation |editor1=Frederic J. Kottke |editor2=Paul M. Ellwood |publisher=Saunders |year=1966 |accessdate=2012-02-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |editor=Frank H. Krusen. Associate: Frederic J. Kottke [and] Paul M. Ellwood Jr. |url=http://openlibrary.org/books/OL4577108M/Handbook_of_physical_medicine_and_rehabilitation |title=Handbook of physical medicine and rehabilitation. |publisher=Saunders |year=1971 |accessdate=2012-02-05}}</ref> and received the 1971 [[American Congress of Rehabilitation Medicine#Gold Key Award|Gold Key]],<ref name="acrm.org - Gold Key Award">{{cite web|url=http://www.acrm.org/gold-key-award |title=Gold Key Award Winners |publisher=[[American Congress of Rehabilitation Medicine]] |accessdate=5 February 2012 }}{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> physical medicine’s highest award. In 1973<ref name="who"/> he founded Interstudy, a health policy think tank based in [[Minnesota]], where he served as Executive Director. He served as the founder and president of the Jackson Hole Group from 1971 to 2002.
==Health maintenance organizations and managed competition== {{main|Health maintenance organization}} In 1970<ref name="who"/> Ellwood was invited to consult with President [[Richard Nixon|Nixon's]] staff to reshape national health policy, where he advanced the idea of giving consumers a choice among health plans that would compete on price and quality. He coined the term Health Maintenance Organization, or HMO, to describe groups of physicians who were pre-paid on a per-patient basis ([[Capitation (healthcare)|capitation]]) instead of a [[fee-for-service]] arrangement. While the term "HMO" was Ellwood’s, this institutional model already existed in the form of the non-profit [[Kaiser Permanente|Kaiser health plan]] in California. Ellwood argued that creating a system of many competing HMOs would give health providers an incentive to keep patients well while driving down health care costs. Doctors would promote [[preventive medicine]] and would be less inclined to order costly procedures that had not been proven to improve health outcomes. Ellwood’s work with the [[Nixon administration]] culminated in the passage of the [[Health Maintenance Organization Act of 1973]].<ref name="Q&A"/> The result was a dramatic change to the landscape of health care in the United States: the proliferation of HMOs, [[Preferred Provider Organization]]s (PPOs), and [[Managed Care#Independent Practice Association|Independent Provider Associations]] (IPAs) alongside traditional [[fee-for-service]] arrangements.
In 1971, Ellwood founded the Jackson Hole Group, a "loosely organized but highly regarded" group of politicians, providers, and policymakers who came together in the town of [[Jackson Hole, Wyoming]] to discuss ideas for changing the health care incentive structure.<ref name="Q&A"/> A key member of the group was [[Alain Enthoven]], a [[Stanford]] [[economist]] who was instrumental in shaping the concept of "managed competition" in health care. By influencing policy, as well as the decision-making of some in the [[Health care industry|health care]] and [[insurance]] industries, he and his colleagues would have a major impact on the changing shape of health care for decades.<ref>See for instance "Jackson Hole Revisited: How a Group of Health Policy Thinkers Transformed the Nation’s Healthcare System" Health Leaders, June 2001; [http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m3257/is_n11_v48/ai_16443634/ Richard L. Clarke, "Paul M. Ellwood, MD: Reforming Health Care from Jackson Hole," Healthcare Financial Management, November 1994]; and [http://www.ama-assn.org/amednews/2002/06/10/gvsa0610.htm Amy Snow Landa, amednews staff, "''Jackson Hole Group Hopes to Spark a Revival''"], American Medical Association, amednews.com, June 10, 2002.</ref>
==Controversy over HMOs== Subsequently, when the [[Bill Clinton|Clinton]] administration was grappling with [[health care reform]], the Jackson Hole Group, according to the [[New York Times]], was "one of the most important influences in the shaping of the [[Clinton health care plan of 1993|Clinton plan]]."<ref name="Toner1993-02-28NYTimes">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/02/28/business/hillary-clinton-s-potent-brain-trust-on-health-reform.html |title=Hillary Clinton’s Potent Brain Trust on Health Reform |last=Toner |first=Robin |date=1993-02-28 |publisher=[[The New York Times]] |pages=section 3, page 1 |accessdate=5 February 2012}}</ref> The plan was called managed competition, and two of its most prominent advocates from the Jackson Hole Group were Ellwood and [[Alain Enthoven]]. In essence, the concept was that groups of [[health care provider]]s and [[insurance|insurers]] would compete with each other to get the business of large [[cooperative]]s seeking [[insurance]]. In the end the [[Clinton health care plan of 1993|Clinton reform plan]] collapsed. By then, the Jackson Hole Group had distanced itself due to disagreement about the degree of regulation the plan sought to impose, and Ellwood had become a pioneer in outcomes management.<ref>See Emling. Also [http://www.ama-assn.org/amednews/2002/06/10/gvsa0610.htm Amy Snow Landa, amednews staff, "''Jackson Hole Group Hopes to Spark a Revival''"], American Medical Association, amednews.com, June 10, 2002. For Ellwood’s critique of the Clinton plan, see Paul M. Ellwood, "Balance the Health Budget," [[The New York Times]] editorial, December 6, 1993, p. 10.</ref>
The spread of HMOs and other pre-paid health plans has spawned significant debate about the impact on quality of care. From the beginning, critics argued that pre-paid competitive plans like HMOs provided incentives for doctors and hospitals to "skimp" on care.<ref>"Health Care: the Cost Crisis is Over – But What about Quality?" [[Business Week]], October 21, 1985.</ref> Many have complained that the plans restrict providers’ autonomy and patients’ choice of doctors. On the left, advocates of a [[Health care in Canada|Canadian style government health plan]] have argued that the Managed Competition approach enriches the insurance industry at patient and taxpayer expense and relies naively on free market forces.<ref>Erik Eckholm, "On ‘Managed Competition’: Primer on Health-Care Idea," [[The New York Times]], May 1, 1993, provides a discussion over managed competition, including critiques from both the left and right.</ref> Many proponents of the managed competition approach, including Ellwood, argue that regulations built into the legislation have undermined the market competition that was meant to enable patients and providers to choose among plans based on quality and cost.<ref>{{cite journal |last=[[Paul Starr|Starr, Paul]] |date=Winter 1976 |title=The Undelivered Health System |journal=[[The Public Interest]] |issue=42 |url=http://www.nationalaffairs.com/public_interest/detail/the-undelivered-health-system |accessdate=2012-02-05}}</ref><ref name="pmid3710412">{{Cite journal |last1=Ellwood Jr |first1=P. M. |last2=Paul |first2=B. A. |title=But what about quality? |journal=Health Affairs (Project Hope) |volume=5 |issue=1 |pages=135–140 |year=1986 |pmid=3710412 |url=http://content.healthaffairs.org/content/5/1/135.full.pdf |doi=10.1377/hlthaff.5.1.135}}</ref> Ellwood has repeatedly expressed disappointment with the way his concepts played out. "What went wrong?" he reflected in 2011. "Political expediency in the initial plan designed to promote HMO growth led to the inclusion of three mistakes: for-profit plans, independent practice associations, and the failure to include outcome accountability."<ref>American Hospital Association interview, p. 16.</ref> Ellwood was particularly adamant about the last. Without measures of health outcomes, which he had advocated from the beginning, there was no way to really know how the changes in health care organization were affecting patients. More important, there was no way to ensure that patients and providers were making good decisions. And there was no way to hold health providers accountable, to ensure that they were not reducing costs in ways that hurt patients.<ref>For a discussion of the debates over HMOs and the evolution of Ellwood’s thinking, see [https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/08/magazine/but-what-about-quality.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm Lisa Belkin, "But What About Quality?"] [[The New York Times Magazine]], December 8, 1996.</ref>
==Outcomes management== Ellwood’s concern about the importance of measuring health outcomes that would hold health providers accountable for quality dated to the mid-1960s. In 1968, as an adviser to the [[Lyndon B. Johnson|Johnson]] administration, he devised the plans for the establishment of U.S. [[Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality]] (AHRQ). He would become increasingly vocal about the need for evidence-based medicine and outcomes accountability.
In 1988, he was invited by the [[Massachusetts Medical Society]], which publishes the [[New England Journal of Medicine]], to deliver their annual Shattuck Lecture. He called for "a national data base containing information and analysis on clinical, financial, and health outcomes that estimates as best we can the relation between medical interventions and health outcomes, as well as the relation between health outcomes and money."<ref name="pmid3367968">{{Cite journal |last1=Ellwood |first1=P. M. |title=Outcomes Management (Presented as the 99th Shattuck Lecture to the Annual Meeting of the Massachusetts Medical Society on May 21, 1988.) |doi=10.1056/NEJM198806093182329 |journal=New England Journal of Medicine |volume=318 |issue=23 |pages=1549–1556 |year=1988 |pmid=3367968 |pmc=}}</ref> He envisioned a sort of health plan "report card" that would allow patients to make informed choices among health plans based on health outcomes for specific conditions and patients’ reports of their satisfaction. He argues that there is extraordinary variation in the quality-performance of different doctors and health institutions, yet patients, insurers, policymakers and even other doctors have few tools for assessing quality. Similarly, doctors and patients often choose medical interventions with only limited information about the effectiveness of various treatments and how they impact patients’ quality of life; a health outcomes data base would vastly improve the information available when making such decisions. Finally, a health outcomes data-base would guide policymakers and large providers in the overall design of health systems. The [[Mayo Clinic]] and some health providers have begun to experiment with outcomes management.<ref name="pmid7988991">{{Cite journal |last1=Steinwachs |first1=D. M. |last2=Wu |first2=A. W. |last3=Skinner |first3=E. A. |title=How will outcomes management work? |journal=Health Affairs (Project Hope) |volume=13 |issue=4 |pages=153–162 |year=1994 |pmid=7988991 |url=http://content.healthaffairs.org/content/13/4/153.long |doi=10.1377/hlthaff.13.4.153}}</ref>
==Family== Ellwood and his former wife, Elizabeth Ann Schwenk,<ref name="who"/> have three children: Deborah Ellwood, who directs a national consortium of community foundations; Cynthia Ellwood, a regional superintendent in the [[Milwaukee Public Schools|Milwaukee school system]]; and [[David T. Ellwood|David Ellwood]], Dean of the [[Kennedy School]] at [[Harvard]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/08/magazine/but-what-about-quality.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm |title=But What About Quality? |last=Belkin |first=Lisa |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=8 December 1996 |accessdate=6 February 2012}}</ref> On December 8, 1996, The [[New York Times Magazine]] ran back-to-back stories about Paul Ellwood and David Ellwood under the cover banner, "What Have the Ellwoods Done to America?" – a reference to Paul Ellwood’s role in reshaping American health care and his son’s role in reshaping the [[Social programs in the United States|American welfare system]].<ref>The cover subheading read, "The visionary father transformed the American way of health. The visionary son redefined the American way of welfare. Now both are struggling to rescue their reforms." Lisa Belkin, "[https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/08/magazine/but-what-about-quality.html But What About Quality?]" (on Paul Ellwood), and Jason DeParle, "Mugged by Reality" (on David Ellwood), [[The New York Times Magazine]], December 8, 1996.</ref> In 2000, Paul Ellwood married Barbara Winch, a former academic health science center executive. They now reside in Bellingham, WA.
